docs.lead_paragraph: ABOUT four years ago, Dr. Robert Vogt-Lowell started putting money into what he now considers to be his best investment yet: medical offices for his pediatric cardiology practice. He and his wife, Arlene, first bought a 2,200-square-foot office condominium in the Miami suburb of Kendall. Two years later, they bought a 1,500-square-foot unit nearby, in Miami Lakes. And they would like to buy space eventually in Pembroke Pines, where he also sees patients.

headline.main: A Doctor in the House? Yes, and He Owns It, Too

docs.abstract: Article on new trend in which medical doctors are investing in medical office properties; says one of biggest draws of medical buildings for investors is stable tenant base; holds building owners say doctors tend to have longer leases and renewal rates of 90 percent or higher; photo; graph; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: More and more health care professionals are investing in office space, snapping up everything from office condos to shares in medical buildings.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE faithful, dressed in business suits or surgical scrubs, gathered here last month to pray for a miracle. At Our Lady of Grace, an old stone church next to St. Mary Hospital, about 400 nurses, doctors, aides, technicians, community leaders and residents bowed their heads and asked for a way out of fiscal distress, economic pressure and the looming specter of lost jobs and closed doors.
docs.snippet: THE faithful, dressed in business suits or surgical scrubs, gathered here last month to pray for a miracle.     At Our Lady of Grace, an old stone church next to St. Mary Hospital, about 400 nurses, doctors, aides, technicians, community leaders and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Relenting to pressure from state government officials, Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that it would begin carrying Plan B, an emergency contraception pill, in all of its United States pharmacies by the end of the month. But in a move that rankled some women's groups, Wal-Mart said that it would allow pharmacists who object to filling a Plan B prescription to refer customers to another pharmacist and, in some cases, to another pharmacy.

headline.main: In Reversal, Wal-Mart Will Sell Contraceptive

docs.abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, relenting to pressure from state officials, says it will begin carrying Plan B, emergency contraception pill, in all of its US pharmacies by end of month; will allow pharmacists who object to filling Plan B prescriptions to refer customers to another pharmacist and, in some cases, to another pharmacy (M)
docs.snippet: Relenting to pressure from state government officials, Wal-Mart said that it wouldbegin carrying Plan B in all of its U.S. stores by the end of the month.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past two years, Nassau County's fiscally troubled health care agency revamped itself, refinanced its debt, cut 900 jobs, changed presidents and planned to break even by the end of 2005. Instead, it is still in the red and is fast running out of money. The agency, the Nassau Health Care Corporation, ended the year with an $11 million deficit, $5 million more than projected, and a bigger gap looms this year. So now, new bailout plans are afoot, calling for new controls, a new administrator and a cash infusion of as much as $98 million.

headline.main: Another Bailout Is Sought For Nassau Health Agency

docs.abstract: Nassau County's health care agency, Nassau Health Care Corp, is still in red and running out of money despite having refinanced its debt, revamped itself and cut 900 jobs; new bailout plans are afoot, calling for new controls, new administrator, and cash infusion of as much as $98 million (M)
docs.snippet: The Nassau Health Care Corporation ended 2005 with an $11 million deficit, $5 million more than projected, and a bigger gap looms this year.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the last decade, more and more immigrants are delaying care or retreating to bootleg drugs and unlicensed practitioners.

docs.lead_paragraph: With a heavy snow pelting them, a ring of pickets stood outside Sikorsky Aircraft's main plant here today, as they have since a week ago Monday, and made it clear that the company's managers were not the only ones digging in for a long fight. Roughly 3,600 teamsters from Local 1150, many of whom build helicopters and other critical parts for the company's military and commercial clients, walked off the job on Feb. 20 in a dispute over the company's plan to charge them more for their health care benefits.

headline.main: Sikorsky and Striking Workers Say They Are Dug In

docs.abstract: Sikorsky Aircraft and striking workers refuse to budge on contract issues nearly two weeks after walkout; main stumbling point is health care benefits; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Strikers in Stratford, Conn., made it clear that the aircraft company's managers were not the only ones digging in for a long fight.

docs.lead_paragraph: JetBlue is trying to raise fares in a bid to restore profits after surging fuel prices caused it to lose $42.4 million in the fourth quarter.

headline.main:
In Search of Profitability, 
JetBlue Increases Prices

docs.snippet: JetBlue is trying to raise fares in a bid to restore profits after surging fuel prices caused it to lose $42.4 million in the fourth quarter.

docs.lead_paragraph: YOU remember the great real estate crash of the 1990's, don't you? In New York, inflation-adjusted prices dropped almost a third in less than a decade. The fall was even worse in Los Angeles, and it wasn't pretty in Boston, San Francisco or Washington, either. Thousands of families were forced into much smaller homes. Many have never lived as well as they did in those giddy pre-crash years. It was a painful preview of what the dot-com meltdown of 2000 would bring.

headline.main: Don't Fear The Bubble That Bursts

docs.snippet: The real estate slump of 2006 offers a chance to puncture the myth that we should all be rooting for high house prices.

docs.lead_paragraph: Next to ''confessional solo show'' and ''multimedia Greek tragedy,'' probably no theatrical form generates as little enthusiasm as the evening of one-acts -- which is a shame, since there's so much to recommend it. First, brevity. Second, more playwrights increases the chance of seeing the next David Mamet. Most of all, some great ideas just can't sustain an entire play. For example, the Naked Angels' enjoyable potpourri of seven shorts ''The Mag-7'' concludes with an incredibly clever piece of meta-theater by Itamar Moses, which, if it went on for much longer, would have been insufferable. ''Untitled Short Play'' asks the question: Why did I write this in the first place?

headline.main: Seven Dramas Illustrate the Merits of Staging Short Plays

docs.snippet: The Naked Angels' enjoyable potpourri of seven shorts concludes with an incredibly clever piece of meta-theater by Itamar Moses.

docs.lead_paragraph: Having struggled to fathom Medicare's new drug coverage, tens of thousands of beneficiaries are perplexed to find themselves actively enrolled in two prescription drug plans at the same time. Shirley D. Beer, who lives in a mobile home here in western Pennsylvania, illustrates the predicament. Mrs. Beer was assigned to one insurance plan by the federal government, then exercised her right to choose another plan and now seems deeply embedded in both.

headline.main: In Medicare Maze, Some Find They're Tangled in 2 Drug Plans

docs.snippet: A result of "computer glitches," the situation leaves patients at risk of being charged two premiums or incorrect co-payments.
